facts.text: Ajmer Singh, aged about 22, was tried for the murder of Bagher Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MAHAJAN J.-Ajmer Singh, a young man of about 22 years of age was tried for the murder of Bagher Singh, his first cous

facts.text: Sessions Judge of Ferozepore acquitted Ajmer Singh on 13th May 1950 in Trial No. 28 of 1950 and Case No. 5 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and was acquitted by the Sessions Judge of Ferozepore by his judgment dated 13th May, 1950. On appeal by the State Government, the order of acquittal was set

facts.text: High Court set aside acquittal and convicted Ajmer Singh under section 304 IPC, sentenced to ten years rigorous imprisonment on 14th September 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the State Government, the order of acquittal was set aside by the High Court and the appellant was convicted under section 304, Indian Penal Code,

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave against High Court decision.

facts.text: Nikka Singh had three sons: Bhagwan Singh, Lal Singh, and Sunder Singh.

anchor.surface_text: One Nikka Singh had three sons, Bhagwan Singh, Lal Singh and Sunder Singh. Bhagwan Singh died issueless some years ago and disputes arose between Lal Singh

facts.text: Bhagwan Singh died issueless some years ago.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwan Singh died issueless some years ago and disputes arose between Lal Singh and his brother Sundar Singh in regard to the division of the property of

facts.text: Disputes arose between Lal Singh and Sunder Singh over division of Bhagwan Singh's property; Sunder in possession, Lal obtained decrees, Sunder declined to restore possession.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwan Singh died issueless some years ago and disputes arose between Lal Singh and his brother Sundar Singh in regard to the division of the property of B

facts.text: Relations between Lal Singh and Sunder Singh were considerably strained; not even on speaking terms for some time.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this litigation the relations between Lal Singh and Sunder Singh were considerably strained and it is said that for some time they were not even

facts.text: Lal Singh married to Mst. Dhan Kaur; sons Bagher Singh (murdered) and Arjan Singh (PW 5).

anchor.surface_text: Lal Singh is married to Mst. Dhan Kaur and from her he had two sons. One of them Bagher Singh was murdered and the other, Arjan Singh, is P. W. 5.

facts.text: Ajmer Singh is son of Sunder Singh; Banta Singh is his real brother.

anchor.surface_text: Accused Ajmer Singh is the son of Sunder Singh and Banta Singh is his real brother. Ajmer Singh is married to Jagir Kaur and Banta Singh to Kartar Kaur.

facts.text: On evening of 27th January 1948, Jagir Kaur complained to her father-in-law that Ajmer Singh pawned her ear-rings for gambling debts.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged by the prosecution that on the evening of the 27th January, 1948, Jagir Kaur complained to her fatherin-law that her husband had pawned her

facts.text: On morning of 28th January 1948, Banta Singh inquired from Ajmer Singh about ear-rings; Ajmer said pawned to Banta Singh Mazhbi.

anchor.surface_text: On the morning of the 28th Banta Singh inquired from Ajmer Singh about this matter and he replied that he had pawned the ear- rings to one Banta Singh

facts.text: Ajmer Singh, Banta Singh, and Teja Singh went to Banta Singh Mazhbi, asked for return of ear-rings; Mazhbi denied, offered Rs. 30 if Ajmer took oath.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after this Ajmer Singh, Banta Singh and one Teja Singh went to Banta Singh Mazhbi and asked him to return the ear- rings but the latter replied t

facts.text: Lal Singh present at Mazhbi conversation, supported Mazhbi, leading to exchange of hot words with Ajmer, Banta, Teja; parties dispersed without blows.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that Lal Singh was also present when this conversation took place and took up cudgels on behalf of Banta Singh Mazhbi and this led to an exc

facts.text: At sunset on 28th January 1948, Lal Singh and Sunder Singh abused each other from their houses opening into common courtyard.

anchor.surface_text: At about sunset the same day Lal Singh and his brother Sunder Singh started abusing each other from their respective houses which open out into a commo

facts.text: Arjan Singh, Bagher Singh, and Ujagar Singh Mazhbi came to Lal Singh's house upon hearing abuse.

anchor.surface_text: This wordy warfare between the two brothers attracted the attention of Arjan Singh, Bagher Singh and one Ujagar Singh Mazhbi who on hearing the noise cam

facts.text: Lal Singh challenged Sunder Singh to come out in the open, supported by three others.

anchor.surface_text: Lal Singh finding himself supported by three others threw out a challenge to Sunder Singh and told him to come out in the open.

facts.text: Sunder Singh, Banta Singh, Ajmer Singh, and Teja Singh accepted challenge, rushed out armed with spears.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that Sunder Singh, his two, sons Banta Singh and Ajmer Singh, and Teja Singh, a cousin of theirs, accepted the challenge and rushed out of th

facts.text: Teja Singh and Banta Singh attacked Lal Singh and Dhan Kaur with spears, inflicting injuries.

anchor.surface_text: Teja Singh and Banta Singh were armed with spears and they made an attack on Lal Singh and Dhan Kaur and inflicted on their persons a number of injuries

facts.text: Ajmer Singh armed with spear, plunged into chest of Bagher Singh who collapsed and died almost instantaneously.

anchor.surface_text: . Ajmer Singh, it is said, was armed with a spear and he plunged his weapon into the chest of Bagher Singh who collapsed and died almost instantaneously.

facts.text: Arjan Singh reported incident at police station at 11:45 p.m. after 7 miles travel, stated Ajmer Singh dealt barchha blow to Bagher Singh's chest.

anchor.surface_text: Arjan Singh soon after reported this incident at the police station after travelling a distance of about seven miles at 11-45 p. m. He gave to the police

facts.text: Police arrested Sunder Singh, Teja Singh, Banta Singh; Ajmer Singh not found initially.

anchor.surface_text: The police arrested Sunder Singh, Teja Singh and Banta Singh but the appellant could not be found.

facts.text: Ajmer Singh apprehended on 4th December 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Ajmer Singh was apprehended on 4th December, 1948, and as above stated, was tried by the learned Sessions Judge of Ferozepore and acquitted,

facts.text: Sunder Singh, Teja Singh, Banta Singh prosecuted under 302/34 IPC, convicted under 324 IPC: Banta and Teja 2 years RI, Sunder 6 months RI.

facts.text: On appeal, Sunder Singh acquitted, sentences on Banta and Teja reduced; lenient view as sudden fight between near relatives.

facts.text: Bagher Singh died from one blow; injuries to Lal Singh and Dhan Kaur not very serious.

anchor.surface_text: Bagher Singh died as a result of one blow and injuries on the person of Lal Singh and Dhan Kaur were not very serious

issues.text: Whether there were compelling reasons for setting aside the order of acquittal and whether due weight was given to the trial judge's opinion on credibility of witnesses

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel submitted that the High Court was in error in the view that when a strong prima facie case is made out against an accused person it is his duty to explain the circumstances appearing in evidence against him and he cannot take shelter behind the presumption of innocence and cannot state that the law entitles him to keep his lips sealed. We think this criticism is well founded.

issues.text: Whether it was the duty of the accused to explain circumstances against him or whether he can rely on presumption of innocence post-acquittal

anchor.surface_text: After an order of acquittal has been made the presumption of innocence is further reinforced by that order, and that being so, the trial courts decision can be reversed not on the ground that the accused had failed to explain the circumstances appearing against him but only for very substantial and compelling reasons.

issues.text: Whether the trial was vitiated due to defective examination of the accused under section 342 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued that the trial held by the Sessions Judge was vitiated as the examination of the appellant was number in accordance with the provisions of section 342, Criminal Procedure Code. There is considerable force in the point that the examination of the appellant by the Sessions Judge was detective.

issues.text: Whether the defective procedure under section 342 CrPC occasioned any prejudice to the accused

arguments.court_reasoning: We think this criticism is well founded

arguments.claim: Arjan Singh's testimony reliable; selected Ajmer specifically soon after occurrence; no material discrepancies

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to believe that without there being any truth in the fact that the appellant struck Bagher Singh with a barchha, Arjan Singh selected the appellant and ascribed to him that part soon after the occurrence. There are no material discrepancies in the statements made by Arjan Singh on different occasions

arguments.claim: Minor discrepancies exaggerated by Sessions Judge; hypercritical view

anchor.surface_text: and in our view the reasons given by the learned Sessions Judge for rejecting his testimony are not convincing. We agree with the High Court that there are no sufficient reasons for distrusting his evidence... It seems that the learned Sessions Judge took too exaggerated a view of the minor discrepancies

arguments.claim: No mistake in identity possible; few participants; corroborated by Lal Singh and Dhan Kaur

anchor.surface_text: The number of persons who took part in the quarrel was not more than seven or eight and the blows inflicted were few, and in these circumstances Arjan Singh could have made no mistake as to the identity of the person who struck Bagher Singh fatally. This part of his statement is corroborated

arguments.claim: Bishandas tendered only for cross-exam; cryptic statement insufficient to conclude Ajmer absent

anchor.surface_text: Bishandas, whose statement considerably impressed him, was only tendered for cross-examination and never made a full statement about the happenings of the 28th morning. The statement made by him is somewhat cryptic and from this it cannot be definitely concluded that Ajmer Singh was not present

arguments.claim: No withholding of independent witnesses; Ujagar tendered, no questions asked by defence

anchor.surface_text: Ujagar Singh, the other so-called independent witness, was tendered for cross-examination but the defence did not ask him a single question about the happenings of the 28th. The argument therefore that the prosecution withheld from court independent witnesses who had witnessed the occurrence is without any substance

arguments.claim: Defence led no evidence of different fight or Ajmer's absence

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the defence also led no evidence to prove that the fight took place in a manner different from the one described by the prosecution witnesses, or that Ajmer Singh was not present on the occasion

arguments.claim: High Court had full power under s417 CrPC to review evidence in acquittal appeal; exercised properly

anchor.surface_text: In an appeal under section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure the High Court had full power to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and we are satisfied that it did not in any way exercise it wrongly

arguments.claim: No obligation to explain injuries on defence side (Kartar Kaur, Ujagar Singh)

anchor.surface_text: The injuries on the person of Kartar Kaur and Ujagar Singh were not proved to have been inflicted at the time of the occurrence and were of no consequence. The prosecution was under no obligation to explain how they came about

arguments.claim: s342 requires separate questions on each material circumstance; not discharged by reading committing court statement

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that when the Sessions Judge is required by that section to make the examination of the accused, his duty is not discharged by merely reading over the questions and answers to the accused put in the committing magistrates court... The accused must be questioned separately about each material circumstance which is intended to be used against him.

holdings.text: After an order of acquittal has been made the presumption of innocence is further reinforced by that order, and that being so, the trial courts decision can be reversed not on the ground that the accused had failed to explain the circumstances appearing against him but only for very substantial and compelling reasons.

anchor.surface_text: After an order of acquittal has been made the presumption of innocence is further reinforced by that order, and that being so, the trial courts decision can be reversed not on the ground that the accused had failed to explain the circumstances appearing against him but only for ,very substantial and companypelling reasons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court agrees with petitioner's criticism of High Court's view that accused must explain circumstances post-acquittal; presumption strengthened by acquittal order requires substantial reasons for reversal.

holdings.text: We are on the whole inclined to agree with the view expressed by the High Court [on credibility of prosecution witnesses after careful review of evidence].

anchor.surface_text: As the courts below expressed divergent opinions on the credibility of the prosecution witnesses, we had to read the evidence adduced in the case with great care and after doing so, we are on the whole inclined to agree with the view expressed by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court independently reviewed evidence due to divergent lower court opinions and found High Court's credibility assessment preferable.

holdings.text: When the Sessions Judge is required by section 342 CrPC to examine the accused, his duty is not discharged by merely reading over the questions and answers from the committing magistrate's court; the accused must be questioned separately about each material circumstance intended to be used against him.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that when the Sessions Judge is required by that section to make the examination of the accused, his duty is not discharged by merely reading over the questions and answers to the accused put in the committing magistrates court... The accused must be questioned separately about each material circumstance which is intended to be used against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies requirements of s342 CrPC, citing Tara Singh v. State; examination must afford fair opportunity to explain specific circumstances.

holdings.text: The defective procedure followed by the Sessions Judge under section 342 CrPC has not occasioned any prejudice to the accused; the trial is not vitiated.

anchor.surface_text: but on further thought we have reached the conclusion that the High Court was right in the view that the defective procedure followed by the Sessions Judge in this respect has not occasioned any prejudice to the accused. The facts of the case are free from any complication and the point in issue was a simple one

holdings.reasoning_summary: Simple facts, accused aware of case through cross-examination and prior statement; no damage from perfunctory exam; cites general rule that not every s342 error vitiates trial.

holdings.text: In an appeal under section 417 CrPC, the High Court had full power to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and it did not exercise that power wrongly.

anchor.surface_text: In -an appeal under section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure the High Court had full power to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal was founded and we are satisfied that it did number in any way exercise it wrongly The injuries on the person of Kartar Kaur and under Singh were number proved

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirms High Court's jurisdiction and proper exercise in reviewing acquittal evidence.

holdings.text: Every error or omission in compliance with section 342 CrPC does not necessarily vitiate a trial.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that every error or omission number in companypliance with the provisions of section 342 does number necessarily vitiate a trial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled principle applied to facts where no prejudice found.

holdings.text: The prosecution was under no obligation to explain [minor injuries on persons of Kartar Kaur and Ujagar Singh not proved to have been inflicted at the time of occurrence].

anchor.surface_text: The injuries on the person of Kartar Kaur and under Singh were number proved to have been inflicted at the time of the occurrence and were of numberconsequence. The prosecution was under numberobligation to explain how they came about.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Injuries not linked to occurrence; no duty on prosecution to explain irrelevant injuries.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that when the Sessions Judge is required by that section to make the examination of the accused, his duty is not discharged by merely reading over the questions and answers to the accused put in the committing magistrates court... The accused must be questioned separately about each material circumstance which is intended to be used against him.

As the courts below expressed divergent opinions on the credibility of the prosecution witnesses, we had to read the evidence adduced in the case with great care and after doing so, we are on the whole inclined to agree with the view expressed by the High Court.
